p: The dangers of extreme heat to health are extensively documented [ 1– 5]. Globally, extreme heat events have become more frequent and intense over recent decades [ 6], and several extreme heat events have been fully attributed to climate change [ 7]. These trends are expected to accelerate, with an average projected global temperature increase of at least 0.2°C per decade by 2030 and as much as 4.8°C by the end of the century relative to a 1986–2005 baseline without aggressive mitigation of greenhouse gas emissions [ 8]. There is high confidence that this warming may have significant adverse health impacts [ 9] and that various preparedness strategies and early warning systems will need to be a part of climate change adaptation planning [ 9, 10]. In many instances, heat is already a threat to health, and current efforts to promote resilience to extreme heat can facilitate climate change adaptation [ 11].
